ItemData.Value:
Patient: Krista Bryan
Date of Surgery: 2021-07-20
Primary Surgeon: Kelly
Surgical Assistants: Hills
Pre-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis and Myelopathy
Post-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis and Myelopathy
Indications: Neck pain and myelopathy: nurick 3 (gait abnormalities), resistant to conservative measures.
Procedures Performed: 1. Anterior diskectomy and fusion at C5-C6 2. Anterior diskectomy and fusion at C6-C7 3. Insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at C5-C6 4. Insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at C6-C7 5. Anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at C5, C6 and C7 6. Spinal Cord Monitoring
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: See anesthesia records
Fluids/Transfusions: See Anesthesia Records
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. The patient was then positioned Supine on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. A standard Left-sided Smith Robinson approach was utilized to get to the anterior cervical spine. The skin, subcutaneous tissue were incised, the platysma was transected, and then blunt dissection was carried out between the sternocleidomastoid and carotid sheath laterally, and trachea and esophogus medially, down to the prevertebral fascia. Once the anterior spine was palpated, fluoroscopy was used to localize and confirm levels. The longus coli was elevated bilaterally from C5 proximally and to C7 distally.
I then proceeded with the diskectomy and interbody fusion of the C5-C6 interspace. First, I smoothed the anterior disk space and resected any osteophyte using a combination of a ronguer and burr. Using a combination of knife, currette, pituitary ronguer, and Kerrison rongeurs, the anterior longitudinal ligament was incised, the disc was excised and the superior and inferior endplates were lightly decorticated to prepare the endplates for fusion, taking care not to disrupt the cortical endplate. This completed the anterior diskectomy of C5-C6 interspace and partially completed the fusion of C5-C6.
I then proceeded with the diskectomy and interbody fusion of the C6-C7 interspace. First, I smoothed the anterior disk space and resected any osteophyte using a combination of a ronguer and burr. Using a combination of knife, currette, pituitary ronguer, and Kerrison rongeurs, the anterior longitudinal ligament was incised, the disc was excised and the superior and inferior endplates were lightly decorticated to prepare the endplates for fusion, taking care not to disrupt the cortical endplate. This completed the anterior diskectomy of C6-C7 interspace and partially completed the fusion of C6-C7.
I then proceeded with the insertion of the interbody implant into the C5-C6 interspace. I again confirmed that the endplates were adequately decorticated and appropriately level. Once I was fully satisfied with the preparation of the endplates, I used trials and measured the disk space to determine the appropriate size of the interbody implant. At the C5-C6 interspace, a 7mm height Allograft implant was selected. I then inserted the interbody implant into the disk space of C5-C6. The final position was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the anterior interbody implant at C5-C6.
I then proceeded with the insertion of the interbody implant into the C6-C7 interspace. I again confirmed that the endplates were adequately decorticated and appropriately level. Once I was fully satisfied with the preparation of the endplates, I used trials and measured the disk space to determine the appropriate size of the interbody implant. At the C6-C7 interspace, a 7mm height Allograft implant was selected. I then inserted the interbody implant into the disk space of C6-C7. The final position was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the anterior interbody implant at C6-C7.
I then proceeded with anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at C5, C6 and C7. I placed an anterior plate spanning C5, C6 and C7. After selecting an appropriately sized plate and length for the screws, I held the plate into position and drilled and tapped the path for the screws. The screws were then inserted sequentially into the vertebral body of C5, C6 and C7 to hold the plate into position. This completed the anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at C5, C6 and C7.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was transferred to the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including anterior diskectomy and fusion at C5-C6, anterior diskectomy and fusion at C6-C7, insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at C5-C6, insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at C6-C7, and the anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at C5-C6 and C6-C7.
anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant)
At the C5-C6 interspace, a 7mm height Allograft implant was selected.
At the C6-C7 interspace, a 7mm height Allograft implant was selected.

Patient: Kim Taylor
Date of Surgery: 2021-03-11
Primary Surgeon: Kelly
Surgical Assistants: Hills
Pre-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis and Flatback Syndrome
Post-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis and Flatback Syndrome
Indications: Low back pain, left leg pain and right leg pain, resistant to conservative measures.
Procedures Performed: Anterior: 1. Anterior diskectomy and fusion at L4-L5 2. Anterior diskectomy and fusion at L5-S1 3. Insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at L4-L5 4. Insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at L5-S1 5. Anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at L4 and L5 6. Spinal Cord Monitoring
Posterior: 1. Inferior facetectomies at T10, T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L4 and L5 2. Posterior column osteotomy at L1-L2 and L2-L3 3. Posterior spinal instrumentation at T10, T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L4, L5 and S1 4. Decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies at L2-L3 5. Instrumentation of the Pelvis with S2AI fixation 6. Posterior Spinal Fusion at T10-T11, T11-T12, T12-L1, L1-L2, L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5 and L5-S1 7. Application of Morselized Allograft, and Local Autograft 8. Spinal Cord Monitoring 9. Application of Cranial Tongs
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: See anesthesia records
Fluids/Transfusions: See Anesthesia Records
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: Anterior: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. The patient was then positioned Supine on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. The anterior approach to the spine was carried out with assistance from our vascular surgeon. A Left-sided incision was made and the approach was carried out down toward the spine. Once the approach was complete, levels were confirmed using fluoroscopy.
I then proceeded with the diskectomy and interbody fusion of the L4-L5 interspace. First, I smoothed the anterior disk space and resected any osteophyte using a combination of a ronguer and burr. Using a combination of knife, currette, pituitary ronguer, and Kerrison rongeurs, the anterior longitudinal ligament was incised, the disc was excised and the superior and inferior endplates were lightly decorticated to prepare the endplates for fusion, taking care not to disrupt the cortical endplate. This completed the anterior diskectomy of L4-L5 interspace and partially completed the fusion of L4-L5.
I then proceeded with the diskectomy and interbody fusion of the L5-S1 interspace. First, I smoothed the anterior disk space and resected any osteophyte using a combination of a ronguer and burr. Using a combination of knife, currette, pituitary ronguer, and Kerrison rongeurs, the anterior longitudinal ligament was incised, the disc was excised and the superior and inferior endplates were lightly decorticated to prepare the endplates for fusion, taking care not to disrupt the cortical endplate. This completed the anterior diskectomy of L5-S1 interspace and partially completed the fusion of L5-S1.
I then proceeded with the insertion of the interbody implant into the L4-L5 interspace. I again confirmed that the endplates were adequately decorticated and appropriately level. Once I was fully satisfied with the preparation of the endplates, I used trials and measured the disk space to determine the appropriate size of the interbody implant. At the L4-L5 interspace, a 10mm height Allograft implant was selected. I then inserted the interbody implant into the disk space of L4-L5. The final position was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the anterior interbody implant at L4-L5.
I then proceeded with the insertion of the interbody implant into the L5-S1 interspace. I again confirmed that the endplates were adequately decorticated and appropriately level. Once I was fully satisfied with the preparation of the endplates, I used trials and measured the disk space to determine the appropriate size of the interbody implant. At the L5-S1 interspace, a 10mm height Allograft implant was selected. I then inserted the interbody implant into the disk space of L5-S1. The final position was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the anterior interbody implant at L5-S1.
I then proceeded with anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at L5 and S1. At the L5 level, I placed an anterior buttress plate. After selecting an appropriately sized plate and length for the screws, I held the plate into position and drilled and tapped the path for the screw. I then inserted the screw to secure the plate to the anterior vertebral body. The plate had adequate coverage of the intervertebral disc space. At the L4 level, I placed an anterior buttress plate. After selecting an appropriately sized plate and length for the screws, I held the plate into position and drilled and tapped the path for the screw. I then inserted the screw to secure the plate to the anterior vertebral body. The plate had adequate coverage of the intervertebral disc space. This completed the anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at L5 and S1.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and we prepared for the next portion of the procedure. I was personally present for the entirety of this portion of the case, including anterior diskectomy and fusion at L4-L5, anterior diskectomy and fusion at L5-S1, insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at L4-L5, insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at L5-S1, and the anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at L4 and L5.
We then turned to the posterior portion of the case.
The patient was then positioned prone on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. Cranial tongs applied to the patient's skull with an appropriate weight for cranial traction was used to position the head. The posterior spine was then prepped and draped in the standard fashion. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the T10 level and distally to the S1 level.
I then proceeded with the inferior facetectomies. The inferior, superior, medial and lateral borders of the inferior facet were identified. The inferior facets on the left and on the right at T10, on the left and on the right at T11, on the left and on the right at T12, on the left and on the right at L1, on the left and on the right at L2, on the left and on the right at L3, on the left at L4 and on the left and on the right at L5 were excised and the bone was morselized to be used as morselized autograft. This completed the inferior facetectomies of T10, T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L4, and L5.
I then proceeded with the posterior column osteotomy. For the posterior column osteotomies, a small rent was made in the interlaminar space to develop the plane between the ligamentum and the dura. A Kerrison rongeur was then used to excise the ligamentum. this was carried out laterally in both directions until the facets were encountered. The superior and inferior facet were both adequately resected to fully release the posterior column. I performed posterior column (Smith-Peterson) osteotomies at L1-L2 and L2-L3 This completed the posterior column osteotomy of L1-L2, and L2-L3.
I then proceeded with the posterior spinal instrumentation. For pedicle screws, the transverse process, pars, and superior facet were used as landmarks to identify the appropriate starting point. After identifying the start point, the superficial cortex was opened at each entry point using a high speed burr. A pedicle probe was then used to navigate down the pedicle, followed by palpating a medial, lateral, superior and inferior pedicle wall, measuring, and tapping if appropriate. At T10, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T11, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T12, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L1, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L2, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L3, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L4, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L5, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At S1, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. This partially completed the posterior spinal instrumentation of T10, T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L4, L5, and S1.
I then proceeded with the decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies. Using a combination of a high-speed burr and Kerrison rongeurs, I performed a partial laminectomy bilaterally at the L2-L3 interspace. First, I resected the dorsal lamina and then excised the ligamentum flavum, exposing the dura. To fully decompress the exiting and traversing nerve roots within the neural foramen and lateral recess, the medial facet was partially excised and a foraminotomy performed on the left and right at the L2-L3 interspace. Following the decompression, the canal and foramen were palpated to confirm an adequate decompression had been completed. This completed the decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies of L2-L3.
I then proceeded with instrumentation of the pelvis. For S2AI screw insertion, the starting point was identified at the inferior and lateral border of the S1 foramen. A probe was used to bore the path of the screw between the two cortices, across the sacroiliac joint, and aimed toward the anterior inferior iliac spine. Once the path was created, the walls of the path were palpated for breaches and the length of the path measured. Using this technique, a polyaxial S2AI screw was placed on the left and a polyaxial S2AI screw was placed on the right. This completed the instrumentation of the pelvis.
To complete the spinal instrumentation, a 5.5mm Cobalt Chrome rod was contoured for the left and a 5.5mm Cobalt Chrome rod was contoured for the right and the rods placed into position and secured with set screws. The set screws were then tightened with a final tightener to the appropriate torque. Intraoperative Xray was used to confirm the final position of all implants. This completed the instrumentation of T10, T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L4, L5, S1, and S2AI.
I then proceeded with the spinal fusion portion of the procedure. The posterior elements of T10, T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L4, L5, and S1 were decorticated. To improve the odds of a successful fusion, 12mg of BMP was placed into the posterior fusion bed. A total of 180(cc) of Morselized allograft and Local Autograft was then impacted into the lateral gutters and into the facet joints. This completed the posterior spinal fusion procedure of T10-T11, T11-T12, T12-L1, L1-L2, L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5, and L5-S1.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of this portion of the case, including inferior facetectomies at T10, T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L4 and L5, posterior column osteotomy at L1-L2 and L2-L3, posterior spinal instrumentation at T10, T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L4, L5 and S1, decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies at L2-L3, pelvic instrumentation at S2AI, and the posterior spinal fusion at T10-T11, T11-T12, T12-L1, L1-L2, L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5 and L5-S1.
decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies
anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant)
At the L4-L5 interspace, a 10mm height Allograft implant was selected.
At the L5-S1 interspace, a 10mm height Allograft implant was selected.

Patient: Ricky Matecki
Date of Surgery: 2021-07-20
Primary Surgeon: Kelly
Surgical Assistants: Hills
Pre-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis and Myelopathy
Post-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis and Myelopathy
Indications: Neck pain and myelopathy: nurick 3 (gait abnormalities), resistant to conservative measures.
Procedures Performed: 1. Decompression with central laminectomy at C3 2. Laminoplasty at C4, C5 and C6 3. Spinal Cord Monitoring 4. Application of Cranial Tongs
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: See anesthesia records
Fluids/Transfusions: See Anesthesia Records
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. Cranial tongs were applied to the patient's skull for positioning and an appropriate weight was selected for cranial traction. The patient was then positioned prone on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the C3 level and distally to the C6 level.
I then proceeded with the decompression with central laminectomy. Using the cranial and caudal edges of the lamina and pars as landmarks, I performed a laminectomy at C3. First, using a combination of a high-speed burr and Kerrison rongeurs, I resected the dorsal lamina. I then excised the underlying ligamentum flavum. Following the decompression, the canal was palpated to confirm an adequate decompression had been completed. This completed the decompression with central laminectomy of C3.
I then proceeded with the laminoplasty. For laminoplasty, an opening and hinge trough was created with a high-speed burr angled perpendicular to the lamina at the lateral mass-lamina junction. This was performed at C4, C5 and C6. After all troughs were completed, greenstick fractures were created to open the lamina at the laminoplasty levels, the ligamentum flavum at the proximal and distal levels was excised, and laminoplasty plates were sequentially secured into place. The spinous processes were trimmed and the canal was palpated to confirm an adequate decompression had been completed. This completed the laminoplasty of C4, C5, and C6.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned onto the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including decompression with central laminectomy at C3, and the laminoplasty at C4, C5 and C6.

Patient: Loretta Ayers
Date of Surgery: 2021-03-15
Primary Surgeon: Kelly
Surgical Assistants: Hills
Pre-operative Diagnosis: Secondary Kyphosis
Post-operative Diagnosis: Secondary Kyphosis
Indications:
Procedures Performed: 1. Posterior spinal instrumentation at T4, T5, T6, T7, T8, T9 and T10 2. Posterior Spinal Fusion at T4-T5, T5-T6, T6-T7, T7-T8, T8-T9 and T9-T10 3. Application of Morselized Allograft 4. Spinal Cord Monitoring 5. Exploration of prior spinal fusion 6. Application of Cranial Tongs
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: See anesthesia records
Fluids/Transfusions: See Anesthesia Records
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. Cranial tongs were applied to the patient's skull for positioning and an appropriate weight was selected for cranial traction. The patient was then positioned prone on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the T4 level and distally to the T10 level.
Once the exposure was completed, I then proceeded with exploration of the prior fusion. Overlying scar was excised from the posterior elements and the prior fusion at T11-T12, T12-L1, L1-L2, L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5 and L5-S1 was inspected and examined for any motion.
I then proceeded with the posterior spinal instrumentation. For pedicle screws, the transverse process, pars, and superior facet were used as landmarks to identify the appropriate starting point. After identifying the start point, the superficial cortex was opened at each entry point using a high speed burr. A pedicle probe was then used to navigate down the pedicle, followed by palpating a medial, lateral, superior and inferior pedicle wall, measuring, and tapping if appropriate. At T4, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left. At T5, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left. At T6, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T7, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T8, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T9, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T10, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. For pedicle hooks, a pedicle finder was carefully placed just under the inferior facet and above the superior facet, until the pedicle was found. Once the pedicle was identified, a pedicle hook was inserted directly toward the inferior pedicle, secured within the residual facet joint on the right at T4. This partially completed the posterior spinal instrumentation of T4, T5, T6, T7, T8, T9, and T10.
To complete the spinal instrumentation, a 5.5mm Titanium rod was contoured for the left and a 5.5mm Titanium rod was contoured for the right and the rods placed into position and secured with set screws. The set screws were then tightened with a final tightener to the appropriate torque. Intraoperative Xray was used to confirm the final position of all implants. This completed the instrumentation of T4, T4, T5, T6, T7, T8, T9, and T10.
I then proceeded with the spinal fusion portion of the procedure. The posterior elements of T4, T5, T6, T7, T8, T9, and T10 were decorticated. To improve the odds of a successful fusion, 12mg of BMP was placed into the posterior fusion bed. Morselized Allograft was then impacted into the lateral gutters and into the facet joints. This completed the posterior spinal fusion procedure of T4-T5, T5-T6, T6-T7, T7-T8, T8-T9, and T9-T10.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned onto the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including posterior spinal instrumentation at T4, T5, T6, T7, T8, T9 and T10, posterior spinal fusion at T4-T5, T5-T6, T6-T7, T7-T8, T8-T9 and T9-T10, and the exploration of prior spinal fusion.

Patient: Max Welton
Date of Surgery: 2021-03-15
Primary Surgeon: Goodwin
Surgical Assistants: Hills
Pre-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis and Myelopathy
Post-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis and Myelopathy
Indications: Neck pain and myelopathy: nurick 3 (gait abnormalities), resistant to conservative measures.
Procedures Performed: 1. Posterior spinal instrumentation at C2, C3, C4, C5 and C6 2. Occiput instrumentation at Occiput 3. Decompression with central laminectomy at C3 and C4 4. Posterior Spinal Fusion at O-C1, C1-C2, C2-C3, C3-C4, C4-C5 and C5-C6 5. Application of Morselized Allograft 6. Spinal Cord Monitoring 7. Application of Cranial Tongs using Mayfield head holder
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: See anesthesia records
Fluids/Transfusions: See Anesthesia Records
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. A Mayfield head holder was applied to the patient's skull for positioning and secured to the bed. The patient was then positioned prone on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the Occiput level and distally to the C6 level.
I then proceeded with the posterior spinal instrumentation. For pedicle screws, the transverse process, pars, and superior facet were used as landmarks to identify the appropriate starting point. After identifying the start point, the superficial cortex was opened at each entry point using a high speed burr. A pedicle probe was then used to navigate down the pedicle, followed by palpating a medial, lateral, superior and inferior pedicle wall, measuring, and tapping if appropriate. At C2, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. For translaminar screw fixation, the starting point was identified using the spinolaminar junction and in the central plane of the contralateral lamina. A burr hole was made to open the superficial cortex, the path was then cannulated and intralaminar screw placed. At C2, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left. For lateral mass screw placement, the entry point was identified using the lateral and medial borders of the lateral mass and superior and inferior borders of the facet. The superficial cortex was opened at each entry point using a high speed burr and the screw path drilled incrementally to the far cortex. At C3, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At C4, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At C5, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At C6, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. This partially completed the posterior spinal instrumentation of C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6.
I then proceeded with the occiput instrumentation. An appropriately sized occipital plate was selected and was placed centered in the midline and just caudal to the external occipital protuberance, but cranial to the foramen magnum. The plate was held in place to identify the appropriate start points for the occipital screws. The occipital screws were drilled incrementally until the anterior cortex was penetrated. The length of the path was measured to acheive bicortical fixation. The screw paths were then tapped and the screws placed, securing the plate to the occiput. This completed the occiput instrumentation of Occiput.
I then proceeded with the decompression with central laminectomy. Using the cranial and caudal edges of the lamina and pars as landmarks, I performed a laminectomy at C3 and C4. First, using a combination of a high-speed burr and Kerrison rongeurs, I resected the dorsal lamina. I then excised the underlying ligamentum flavum. Following the decompression, the canal was palpated to confirm an adequate decompression had been completed. This completed the decompression with central laminectomy of C3, and C4.
To complete the spinal instrumentation, a 4.0mm Titanium rod was contoured for the left and a 4.0mm Titanium rod was contoured for the right and the rods placed into position and secured with set screws. The set screws were then tightened with a final tightener to the appropriate torque. Intraoperative Xray was used to confirm the final position of all implants. This completed the instrumentation of Occiput, C2, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6.
I then proceeded with the spinal fusion portion of the procedure. The posterior elements of C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, and O were decorticated. To improve the odds of a successful fusion, 12mg of BMP was placed into the posterior fusion bed. Morselized Allograft was then impacted into the lateral gutters and into the facet joints. This completed the posterior spinal fusion procedure of O-C1, C1-C2, C2-C3, C3-C4, C4-C5, and C5-C6.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned onto the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including posterior spinal instrumentation at C2, C3, C4, C5 and C6, occiput instrumentation at Occiput, decompression with central laminectomy at C3 and C4, and the posterior spinal fusion at O-C1, C1-C2, C2-C3, C3-C4, C4-C5 and C5-C6.

Patient: Deborah Wehner
Date of Surgery: 2021-03-18
Primary Surgeon: Kelly
Surgical Assistants: Hills
Pre-operative Diagnosis: Flatback Syndrome
Post-operative Diagnosis: Flatback Syndrome
Indications: Low back pain, resistant to conservative measures.
Procedures Performed: Anterior: 1. Insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at L4-L5 2. Insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at L5-S1 3. Anterior diskectomy and fusion at L5-S1 4. Anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at L5 5. Application of Morselized Allograft 6. Spinal Cord Monitoring
Posterior: 1. Posterior spinal instrumentation at L3, L4, L5 and S1 2. Instrumentation of the Pelvis with S2AI fixation 3. Decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies at L3-L4 and L4-L5 4. Posterior column osteotomy at L4-L5 and L5-S1 5. Posterior Spinal Fusion at L3-L4, L4-L5 and L5-S1 6. Application of Morselized Allograft 7. Spinal Cord Monitoring 8. Application of Cranial Tongs
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: See anesthesia records
Fluids/Transfusions: See Anesthesia Records
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: Anterior: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. The patient was then positioned Supine on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. The anterior approach to the spine was carried out with assistance from our vascular surgeon. A Left-sided incision was made and the approach was carried out down toward the spine. Once the approach was complete, levels were confirmed using fluoroscopy.
I then proceeded with the diskectomy and interbody fusion of the L5-S1 interspace. First, I smoothed the anterior disk space and resected any osteophyte using a combination of a ronguer and burr. Using a combination of knife, currette, pituitary ronguer, and Kerrison rongeurs, the anterior longitudinal ligament was incised, the disc was excised and the superior and inferior endplates were lightly decorticated to prepare the endplates for fusion, taking care not to disrupt the cortical endplate. This completed the anterior diskectomy of L5-S1 interspace and partially completed the fusion of L5-S1.
I then proceeded with the insertion of the interbody implant into the L4-L5 interspace. I again confirmed that the endplates were adequately decorticated and appropriately level. Once I was fully satisfied with the preparation of the endplates, I used trials and measured the disk space to determine the appropriate size of the interbody implant. At the L4-L5 interspace, an 8mm height Allograft implant was selected. I then inserted the interbody implant into the disk space of L4-L5. The final position was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the anterior interbody implant at L4-L5.
I then proceeded with the insertion of the interbody implant into the L5-S1 interspace. I again confirmed that the endplates were adequately decorticated and appropriately level. Once I was fully satisfied with the preparation of the endplates, I used trials and measured the disk space to determine the appropriate size of the interbody implant. At the L5-S1 interspace, an 8mm height Allograft implant was selected. I then inserted the interbody implant into the disk space of L5-S1. The final position was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the anterior interbody implant at L5-S1.
I then proceeded with anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at S1. At the L5 level, I placed an anterior buttress plate. After selecting an appropriately sized plate and length for the screws, I held the plate into position and drilled and tapped the path for the screw. I then inserted the screw to secure the plate to the anterior vertebral body. The plate had adequate coverage of the intervertebral disc space. This completed the anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at S1.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and we prepared for the next portion of the procedure. I was personally present for the entirety of this portion of the case, including insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at L4-L5, insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at L5-S1, anterior diskectomy and fusion at L5-S1, and the anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at L5.
We then turned to the posterior portion of the case.
The patient was then positioned prone on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. Cranial tongs applied to the patient's skull with an appropriate weight for cranial traction was used to position the head. The posterior spine was then prepped and draped in the standard fashion. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the L3 level and distally to the S1 level.
I then proceeded with the posterior spinal instrumentation. For pedicle screws, the transverse process, pars, and superior facet were used as landmarks to identify the appropriate starting point. After identifying the start point, the superficial cortex was opened at each entry point using a high speed burr. A pedicle probe was then used to navigate down the pedicle, followed by palpating a medial, lateral, superior and inferior pedicle wall, measuring, and tapping if appropriate. At L3, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L4, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L5, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At S1, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. This partially completed the posterior spinal instrumentation of L3, L4, L5, and S1.
I then proceeded with instrumentation of the pelvis. For S2AI screw insertion, the starting point was identified at the inferior and lateral border of the S1 foramen. A probe was used to bore the path of the screw between the two cortices, across the sacroiliac joint, and aimed toward the anterior inferior iliac spine. Once the path was created, the walls of the path were palpated for breaches and the length of the path measured. Using this technique, a polyaxial S2AI screw was placed on the left and a polyaxial S2AI screw was placed on the right. This completed the instrumentation of the pelvis.
I then proceeded with the decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies. Using a combination of a high-speed burr and Kerrison rongeurs, I performed a partial laminectomy bilaterally at the L3-L4 and L4-L5 interspace. First, I resected the dorsal lamina and then excised the ligamentum flavum, exposing the dura. To fully decompress the exiting and traversing nerve roots within the neural foramen and lateral recess, the medial facet was partially excised and a foraminotomy performed on the left and right at the L3-L4 and L4-L5 interspace. Following the decompression, the canal and foramen were palpated to confirm an adequate decompression had been completed. This completed the decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies of L3-L4, and L4-L5.
I then proceeded with the posterior column osteotomy. For the posterior column osteotomies, a small rent was made in the interlaminar space to develop the plane between the ligamentum and the dura. A Kerrison rongeur was then used to excise the ligamentum. this was carried out laterally in both directions until the facets were encountered. The superior and inferior facet were both adequately resected to fully release the posterior column. I performed posterior column (Smith-Peterson) osteotomies at L4-L5 and L5-S1 This completed the posterior column osteotomy of L4-L5, and L5-S1.
To complete the spinal instrumentation, a 5.5mm Titanium rod was contoured for the left and a 5.5mm Titanium rod was contoured for the right and the rods placed into position and secured with set screws. The set screws were then tightened with a final tightener to the appropriate torque. Intraoperative Xray was used to confirm the final position of all implants. This completed the instrumentation of L3, L4, L5, S1, and S2AI.
I then proceeded with the spinal fusion portion of the procedure. The posterior elements of L3, L4, L5, and S1 were decorticated. To improve the odds of a successful fusion, 12mg of BMP was placed into the posterior fusion bed. A total of 150(cc) of Morselized allograft was then impacted into the lateral gutters and into the facet joints. This completed the posterior spinal fusion procedure of L3-L4, L4-L5, and L5-S1.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of this portion of the case, including posterior spinal instrumentation at L3, L4, L5 and S1, pelvic instrumentation at S2AI, decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies at L3-L4 and L4-L5, posterior column osteotomy at L4-L5 and L5-S1, and the posterior spinal fusion at L3-L4, L4-L5 and L5-S1.

anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant)

At L1, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L2, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. This partially completed the posterior spinal instrumentation of T3, T4, T5, T10, T11, T12, L1, and L2.
I then proceeded with the costovertebral approach with costotransversectomy. For the costotransversectomy, the rib was identified and a subperiosteal dissection was carried out laterally 6-7cm. Once the medial rib was skeletonized and a safe, subperiorsteal plane was confirmed, 5-6cm of the medial rib was transected. This process was completed on the left and on the right at T7 and on the left and on the right at T8, allowing a safe costovertebral approach to the anterior vertebral body. This completed the costovertebral approach with costotransversectomy of T7, and T8.
I then proceeded with a vertebral column resection at the level of T7. A complete central decompression was performed and confirmed extending from the T6 pedicle to the T8 pedicle in order to prevent neural compression after osteotomy closure. A complete facetectomy was performed superiorly and any dorsal bone was removed, allowing the T6 nerve root to be visualized and tracked laterally. Similarly, a complete facetectomy was performed inferiorly, allowing the T7 nerve root to be visualized and tracked laterally. Next, the transverse process was resected and the T7 pedicles were completely skeletonized. The cranial and caudal nerve roots were then free and a full decompression was confirmed from the T6 pedicle to the T8 pedicle. Clamps were then placed on the exiting T6 and T7 nerve roots medial to the dorsal root ganglion and the spinal cord was monitored for any neuromonitoring changes. Once we were satisfied with the neuromonitoring data, the nerve roots were ligated with sutures. In preparation for the vertebral column resection, a unilateral stabilizing rod was placed on the convex side and secured with set screws multiple levels above and below the T7 level. Starting on the concavity, a combination of blunt and electrocautery dissection was used to develop a subperiosteal plane around the entire anterior portion of the T7 body and retractors were held in place to protect the anterior and neural structures. A lateral pedicle body window was developed for accessing the cancellous bone of the vertebral body and using currettes and rongeurs, the accessible cancellous vertebral body was removed, extending up toward the cranial and caudal disk space. The remaining pedicle of T7 was resected down to the dorsal vertebral body, allowing the spinal cord to drift medially. The same process was then carried out on the convexity to access the cancellous vertebral body and remove the convex pedicle. The entire vertebral body was removed except for a thin anterior section, preserving the anterior longitudinal ligament. Discectomies were performed at the T6-T7 and T7-T8, taking care to preserve the endplates. Once the entire body had been removed, a plane was developed between the ventral dural sac and the posterior body wall to be sure the dural sac was completely free from the body wall. An impactor was then used to impact the posterior body wall, completing the vertebral column resection. The dural sac was again inspected to confirm no potential sites of impingement. We then turned toward closure of the resection site. Starting with compression on the convexity, the site was closed through alternating compression on the convexity and slight distraction on the concave side. Once I was satisfied with the closure, rods were secured into place bilaterally with set screws. This completed the vertebral column resection at the T7 level.
I then proceeded with a vertebral column resection at the level of T8. A complete central decompression was performed and confirmed extending from the T7 pedicle to the T9 pedicle in order to prevent neural compression after osteotomy closure. A complete facetectomy was performed superiorly and any dorsal bone was removed, allowing the T7 nerve root to be visualized and tracked laterally. Similarly, a complete facetectomy was performed inferiorly, allowing the T8 nerve root to be visualized and tracked laterally. Next, the transverse process was resected and the T8 pedicles were completely skeletonized. The cranial and caudal nerve roots were then free and a full decompression was confirmed from the T7 pedicle to the T9 pedicle. Clamps were then placed on the exiting T7 and T8 nerve roots medial to the dorsal root ganglion and the spinal cord was monitored for any neuromonitoring changes. Once we were satisfied with the neuromonitoring data, the nerve roots were ligated with sutures. In preparation for the vertebral column resection, a unilateral stabilizing rod was placed on the convex side and secured with set screws multiple levels above and below the T8 level. Starting on the concavity, a combination of blunt and electrocautery dissection was used to develop a subperiosteal plane around the entire anterior portion of the T8 body and retractors were held in place to protect the anterior and neural structures. A lateral pedicle body window was developed for accessing the cancellous bone of the vertebral body and using currettes and rongeurs, the accessible cancellous vertebral body was removed, extending up toward the cranial and caudal disk space. The remaining pedicle of T8 was resected down to the dorsal vertebral body, allowing the spinal cord to drift medially. The same process was then carried out on the convexity to access the cancellous vertebral body and remove the convex pedicle. The entire vertebral body was removed except for a thin anterior section, preserving the anterior longitudinal ligament. Discectomies were performed at the T7-T8 and T8-T9, taking care to preserve the endplates. Once the entire body had been removed, a plane was developed between the ventral dural sac and the posterior body wall to be sure the dural sac was completely free from the body wall. An impactor was then used to impact the posterior body wall, completing the vertebral column resection. The dural sac was again inspected to confirm no potential sites of impingement. We then turned toward closure of the resection site. Starting with compression on the convexity, the site was closed through alternating compression on the convexity and slight distraction on the concave side. Once I was satisfied with the closure, rods were secured into place bilaterally with set screws. This completed the vertebral column resection at the T8 level.
I then proceed with placement of the intervertebral cage. After ensuring the neural structures were completely free and the bony surfaces cranially and caudally were appropriately prepared, the intervertebral distance was measured. The implant was then inserted into the defect, abutting bone superiorly and inferiorly. Intraoperative xray was used to confirm appropriate size, fit, and alignment of the intervertebral implant spanning T7. This completed the insertion of intervertebral biomechanical implant at the T7 level.
I then proceed with placement of the intervertebral cage. After ensuring the neural structures were completely free and the bony surfaces cranially and caudally were appropriately prepared, the intervertebral distance was measured. The implant was then inserted into the defect, abutting bone superiorly and inferiorly. Intraoperative xray was used to confirm appropriate size, fit, and alignment of the intervertebral implant spanning T8. This completed the insertion of intervertebral biomechanical implant at the T8 level.
To complete the spinal instrumentation, a 3.5mm Titanium rod was contoured for the left and a 3.5mm Titanium rod was contoured for the right and the rods placed into position and secured with set screws. On the left side, an accessory rod was connected from T5 to T10 to increase the overall stiffness of the construct. The set screws were then tightened with a final tightener to the appropriate torque. Intraoperative Xray was used to confirm the final position of all implants. This completed the instrumentation of T3, T4, T5, T10, T11, T12, L1, and L2.
I then proceeded with the spinal fusion portion of the procedure. The posterior elements of T3, T4, T5, T6, T7, T8, T9, T10, T11, T12, L1, and L2 were decorticated. To improve the odds of a successful fusion, 12mg of BMP was placed into the posterior fusion bed. Morselized Allograft was then impacted into the lateral gutters and into the facet joints. This completed the posterior spinal fusion procedure of T3-T4, T4-T5, T5-T6, T6-T7, T7-T8, T8-T9, T9-T10, T10-T11, T11-T12, T12-L1, and L1-L2.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned onto the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including inferior facetectomies at T3, T4, T5, T6, T9, T10, T11, T12 and L1, posterior column osteotomy at T4-T5, T5-T6 and T10-T11, decompression with central laminectomy at T6 and T9, posterior spinal instrumentation at T3, T4, T5, T10, T11, T12, L1 and L2, costovertebral approach with costotransversectomy at T7 and T8, vertebral column resection at T7, vertebral column resection at T8, insertion of intervertebral biomechanical implant at T7, insertion of intervertebral biomechanical implant at T8, and the posterior spinal fusion at T3-T4, T4-T5, T5-T6, T6-T7, T7-T8, T8-T9, T9-T10, T10-T11, T11-T12, T12-L1 and L1-L2.
At the T7-T8 interspace, a 10mm height Titanium Nuvasive expandable implant was selected.
low back pain; left leg pain; right leg pain

Patient: Raynard Jones
Date of Surgery: 2021-03-24
Primary Surgeon: Kelly
Surgical Assistants: Hills
Pre-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis and Flatback Syndrome
Post-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis and Flatback Syndrome
Indications: Low back pain, left leg pain and right leg pain, resistant to conservative measures.
Procedures Performed: 1. Inferior facetectomies at T11, T12, L1, L2 and L5 2. Decompression with central laminectomy at L3 3. Reexploration and revision decompression with central laminectomy at L4 4. Posterior spinal instrumentation at T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L5 and S1 5. Instrumentation of the Pelvis with S2AI fixation 6. Extended three column osteotomy (vertebral body partial corpectomy) at L4 7. Posterior Spinal Fusion at T11-T12, T12-L1, L1-L2, L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5 and L5-S1 8. Application of Morselized Allograft, and Local Autograft 9. Spinal Cord Monitoring 10. Exploration of prior spinal fusion 11. Removal of spinal instrumentation 12. Application of Cranial Tongs
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: See anesthesia records
Fluids/Transfusions: See Anesthesia Records
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. Cranial tongs were applied to the patient's skull for positioning and an appropriate weight was selected for cranial traction. The patient was then positioned prone on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the T11 level and distally to the S1 level.
Once the exposure was completed, I then proceeded with removal of the prior spinal instrumentation. The prior instrumentation was identified at L3, L4, L5 and S1, and removed without major difficulty. I then proceeded with exploration of the prior fusion. Overlying scar was excised from the posterior elements and the prior fusion at L3-L4, L4-L5 and L5-S1 was inspected and examined for any motion.
I then proceeded with the inferior facetectomies. The inferior, superior, medial and lateral borders of the inferior facet were identified. The inferior facets on the left and on the right at T11, on the left and on the right at T12, on the left and on the right at L1, on the left and on the right at L2 and on the left and on the right at L5 were excised and the bone was morselized to be used as morselized autograft. This completed the inferior facetectomies of T11, T12, L1, L2, and L5.
I then proceeded with the decompression with central laminectomy. Using the cranial and caudal edges of the lamina and pars as landmarks, I performed a laminectomy at L3. First, using a combination of a high-speed burr and Kerrison rongeurs, I resected the dorsal lamina. I then excised the underlying ligamentum flavum. Following the decompression, the canal was palpated to confirm an adequate decompression had been completed. This completed the decompression with central laminectomy of L3.
I then proceeded with the reexploration and revision decompression with central laminectomy. Using the cranial and caudal edges of the lamina and pars as landmarks, I performed a reexploration and revision laminectomy at L4. Using a combination of a high-speed burr, currettes and Kerrison rongeurs, I carefully dissected off the scar until I was able to safely identify the bony edges and develop a plane between the dura and scar. I removed any dorsal lamina, ligamentum flavum and scar thought to still be causing compression. The central canal was palpated to confirm full decompression of the thecal sac. Following the revision decompression, the canal was palpated to confirm an adequate decompression had been completed. This completed the reexploration and revision decompression with central laminectomy of L4.
I then proceeded with the posterior spinal instrumentation. For pedicle screws, the transverse process, pars, and superior facet were used as landmarks to identify the appropriate starting point. After identifying the start point, the superficial cortex was opened at each entry point using a high speed burr. A pedicle probe was then used to navigate down the pedicle, followed by palpating a medial, lateral, superior and inferior pedicle wall, measuring, and tapping if appropriate. At T11, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T12, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L1, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L2, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L3, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L5, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At S1, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. This partially completed the posterior spinal instrumentation of T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L5, and S1.
I then proceeded with instrumentation of the pelvis. For S2AI screw insertion, the starting point was identified at the inferior and lateral border of the S1 foramen. A probe was used to bore the path of the screw between the two cortices, across the sacroiliac joint, and aimed toward the anterior inferior iliac spine. Once the path was created, the walls of the path were palpated for breaches and the length of the path measured. Using this technique, a polyaxial S2AI screw was placed on the left and a polyaxial S2AI screw was placed on the right. This completed the instrumentation of the pelvis.
I then proceeded with an extended three column osteotomy (partial corpectomy) at the level of L4. The posterior elements of L4 were completely removed. A complete central laminectomy was performed and confirmed at the L3 level in order to prevent compression after osteotomy closure. A temporary rod was placed and starting on the contralateral side, a complete superior facetectomy was performed and any dorsal bone and scar was removed, and the L3 nerve root was visualized and tracked laterally. Then a cut was made through the pars just inferior to the pedicle, and the superior facet of the inferior vertebra was resected, allowing the L4 nerve root to be visualized and tracked laterally. Next, the transverse process was resected. Once the L4 pedicle was completely skeletonized, and the cranial and caudal nerve roots identified and a full decompression was confirmed from the L3 pedicle to the L5 pedicle, a subperiosteal plane was developed around the anterior portion of the L4 body and retractors were held in place to protect the retroperitoneal structures. Next, the pedicle was resected down to the dorsal vertebral body, leaving a lip medially to protect the neural structures. The dura, cranial and caudal nerve roots were protected and a high speed burr was used to develop a defect in the vertebral body. The lateral portion of the pedicle wall was taken down, allowing easier access to the vertebral body and the vertebral body was hollowed out, extending up into the cranial disk space, taking care not to perforate the anterior cortex. The remaining pedicle walls were then resected with a box osteotome. We then placed a temporary rod and repeated the same process on the contralateral pedicle. Once roughly 50% of the vertebral body had been resected, the dorsal wall of the vertebral body was impacted. The nerve roots were checked again and the underside of the thecal sac was palpated to confirm no bony impingement. Once we were satisfied that the thecal sac was fully decompressed circumferentially and that the L3 and L4 nerve roots were completely free, the osteotomy was closed, and the other rod was placed into position and set screws final tightened to lock the osteotomy in position. Intraoperative xray was performed to confirm appropriate alignment. This completed the extended three column osteotomy (vertebral body partial corpectomy) at the L4 level.
To complete the spinal instrumentation, a 5.5mm Cobalt Chrome rod was contoured for the left and a 5.5mm Cobalt Chrome rod was contoured for the right and the rods placed into position and secured with set screws. On the left side, a satellite rod construct was utilized, with the satellite rod spanning L3 to L5. On the right side, a satellite rod construct was utilized, with the satellite rod spanning L3 to L5. The set screws were then tightened with a final tightener to the appropriate torque. Intraoperative Xray was used to confirm the final position of all implants. This completed the instrumentation of T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L5, S1, and S2AI.
I then proceeded with the spinal fusion portion of the procedure. The posterior elements of T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L4, L5, and S1 were decorticated. To improve the odds of a successful fusion, 24mg of BMP was placed into the posterior fusion bed. A total of 180(cc) of Morselized allograft and Local Autograft was then impacted into the lateral gutters and into the facet joints. This completed the posterior spinal fusion procedure of T11-T12, T12-L1, L1-L2, L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5, and L5-S1.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned onto the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including inferior facetectomies at T11, T12, L1, L2 and L5, decompression with central laminectomy at L3, reexploration and revision decompression with central laminectomy at L4, posterior spinal instrumentation at T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L5 and S1, instrumentation of the pelvis with S2AI fixation, extended three column osteotomy (vertebral body partial corpectomy) at L4, posterior spinal fusion at T11-T12, T12-L1, L1-L2, L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5 and L5-S1, exploration of prior spinal fusion, and the removal of spinal instrumentation.
extended three column osteotomy (vertebral body partial corpectomy)

Surgery Description: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. Cranial tongs were applied to the patient's skull for positioning and an appropriate weight was selected for cranial traction. The patient was then positioned prone on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the T12 level and distally to the T12 level.
I then proceeded with the posterior spinal instrumentation. For pedicle screws, the transverse process, pars, and superior facet were used as landmarks to identify the appropriate starting point. After identifying the start point, the superficial cortex was opened at each entry point using a high speed burr. A pedicle probe was then used to navigate down the pedicle, followed by palpating a medial, lateral, superior and inferior pedicle wall, measuring, and tapping if appropriate. At T12, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. This partially completed the posterior spinal instrumentation of T12.
To complete the spinal instrumentation, a None Non-instrumented rod was contoured for the left and a None Non-instrumented rod was contoured for the right and the rods placed into position and secured with set screws. The set screws were then tightened with a final tightener to the appropriate torque. Intraoperative Xray was used to confirm the final position of all implants. This completed the instrumentation of T12.
I then proceeded with the spinal fusion portion of the procedure. The posterior elements of T12, and L1 were decorticated. Morselized Allograft was then impacted into the lateral gutters and into the facet joints. This completed the posterior spinal fusion procedure of T12-L1.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned onto the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including posterior spinal instrumentation at T12, and the posterior spinal fusion at T12-L1.

Posterior: 1. Inferior facetectomies at T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L4 and L5 2. Posterior column osteotomy at T12-L1, L1-L2 and L2-L3 3. Posterior spinal instrumentation at T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L4, L5 and S1 4. Instrumentation of the Pelvis with S2AI fixation 5. Posterior Spinal Fusion at T11-T12, T12-L1, L1-L2, L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5 and L5-S1 6. Application of Morselized Allograft 7. Spinal Cord Monitoring 8. Application of Cranial Tongs
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: 1100
Fluids/Transfusions: -Crystalloids: NAcc -Colloids: 750cc -pRBC's transfused: 1 unit
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: Anterior: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. The patient was then positioned Supine on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. The anterior approach to the spine was carried out with assistance from our vascular surgeon. A Paramedian incision was made and the approach was carried out down toward the spine. Once the approach was complete, levels were confirmed using fluoroscopy.
I then proceeded with the diskectomy and interbody fusion of the L4-L5 interspace. First, I smoothed the anterior disk space and resected any osteophyte using a combination of a ronguer and burr. Using a combination of knife, currette, pituitary ronguer, and Kerrison rongeurs, the anterior longitudinal ligament was incised, the disc was excised and the superior and inferior endplates were lightly decorticated to prepare the endplates for fusion, taking care not to disrupt the cortical endplate. This completed the anterior diskectomy of L4-L5 interspace and partially completed the fusion of L4-L5.
I then proceeded with the diskectomy and interbody fusion of the L5-S1 interspace. First, I smoothed the anterior disk space and resected any osteophyte using a combination of a ronguer and burr. Using a combination of knife, currette, pituitary ronguer, and Kerrison rongeurs, the anterior longitudinal ligament was incised, the disc was excised and the superior and inferior endplates were lightly decorticated to prepare the endplates for fusion, taking care not to disrupt the cortical endplate. This completed the anterior diskectomy of L5-S1 interspace and partially completed the fusion of L5-S1.
I then proceeded with the insertion of the interbody implant into the L4-L5 interspace. I again confirmed that the endplates were adequately decorticated and appropriately level. Once I was fully satisfied with the preparation of the endplates, I used trials and measured the disk space to determine the appropriate size of the interbody implant. At the L4-L5 interspace, a 16mm height Allograft implant was selected. I then inserted the interbody implant into the disk space of L4-L5. The final position was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the anterior interbody implant at L4-L5.
I then proceeded with the insertion of the interbody implant into the L5-S1 interspace. I again confirmed that the endplates were adequately decorticated and appropriately level. Once I was fully satisfied with the preparation of the endplates, I used trials and measured the disk space to determine the appropriate size of the interbody implant. At the L5-S1 interspace, a 15mm height Allograft implant was selected. I then inserted the interbody implant into the disk space of L5-S1. The final position was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the anterior interbody implant at L5-S1.
I then proceeded with anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at S1. At the L5 level, I placed an anterior buttress plate. After selecting an appropriately sized plate and length for the screws, I held the plate into position and drilled and tapped the path for the screw. I then inserted the screw to secure the plate to the anterior vertebral body. The plate had adequate coverage of the intervertebral disc space. At the L5 level, I placed an anterior buttress plate. After selecting an appropriately sized plate and length for the screws, I held the plate into position and drilled and tapped the path for the screw. I then inserted the screw to secure the plate to the anterior vertebral body. The plate had adequate coverage of the intervertebral disc space. This completed the anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at S1.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, Dermabond, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and we prepared for the next portion of the procedure. I was personally present for the entirety of this portion of the case, including anterior diskectomy and fusion at L4-L5, anterior diskectomy and fusion at L5-S1, insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at L4-L5, insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at L5-S1, and the anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at L5.
We then turned to the posterior portion of the case.
The patient was then positioned prone on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. Cranial tongs applied to the patient's skull with an appropriate weight for cranial traction was used to position the head. The posterior spine was then prepped and draped in the standard fashion. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the T11 level and distally to the S1 level.
I then proceeded with the posterior column osteotomy. For the posterior column osteotomies, a small rent was made in the interlaminar space to develop the plane between the ligamentum and the dura. A Kerrison rongeur was then used to excise the ligamentum. this was carried out laterally in both directions until the facets were encountered. The superior and inferior facet were both adequately resected to fully release the posterior column. I performed posterior column (Smith-Peterson) osteotomies at T12-L1, L1-L2 and L2-L3 This completed the posterior column osteotomy of T12-L1, L1-L2, and L2-L3.
To complete the spinal instrumentation, a 5.5mm Cobalt Chrome rod was contoured for the left and a 5.5mm Cobalt Chrome rod was contoured for the right and the rods placed into position and secured with set screws. The set screws were then tightened with a final tightener to the appropriate torque. Intraoperative Xray was used to confirm the final position of all implants. This completed the instrumentation of T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L4, L5, S1, and S2AI.
I then proceeded with the spinal fusion portion of the procedure. The posterior elements of T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L4, L5, and S1 were decorticated. To improve the odds of a successful fusion, 4.2mg of BMP was placed into the posterior fusion bed. A total of 30(cc) of Morselized allograft was then impacted into the lateral gutters and into the facet joints. This completed the posterior spinal fusion procedure of T11-T12, T12-L1, L1-L2, L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5, and L5-S1.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, Dermabond, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of this portion of the case, including inferior facetectomies at T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L4 and L5, posterior column osteotomy at T12-L1, L1-L2 and L2-L3, posterior spinal instrumentation at T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L4, L5 and S1, pelvic instrumentation at S2AI, and the posterior spinal fusion at T11-T12, T12-L1, L1-L2, L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5 and L5-S1.

Surgery Description: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the L5 level and distally to the S1 level.
I then proceeded with the decompression with diskectomy and laminotomy. For a diskectomy, I used the cranial and caudal laminar edges, pars, and facet joints as landmarks. I performed a diskectomy with partial medial facetectomy and foraminotomy on the right at L5-S1 interspace to fully decompress the nerve root. Using a high-speed burr and Kerrison rongeurs, I first performed a foraminotomy and excised the ligamentum flavum. The dural sac was identified and traversing root was protected. The annulus was then incised and the diseased disk materal was removed. Following the decompression, the canal and foramen and lateral recess were palpated to confirm an appropriate decompression had been completed. This completed the decompression with diskectomy and laminotomy of L5-S1.

Patient: Feker Abell
