Surgery Description: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. Cranial tongs were applied to the patient's skull for positioning and an appropriate weight was selected for cranial traction. The patient was then positioned prone on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the C4 level and distally to the T12 level.
I then proceeded with the posterior spinal instrumentation. For lateral mass screw placement, the entry point was identified using the lateral and medial borders of the lateral mass and superior and inferior borders of the facet. The superficial cortex was opened at each entry point using a high speed burr and the screw path drilled incrementally to the far cortex. At C4, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At C5, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. For pedicle screws, the transverse process, pars, and superior facet were used as landmarks to identify the appropriate starting point. After identifying the start point, the superficial cortex was opened at each entry point using a high speed burr. A pedicle probe was then used to navigate down the pedicle, followed by palpating a medial, lateral, superior and inferior pedicle wall, measuring, and tapping if appropriate. At T1, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T10, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T11, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T12, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. This partially completed the posterior spinal instrumentation of C4, C5, T1, T10, T11, and T12.
To complete the spinal instrumentation, a 4.0mm Titanium rod was contoured for the left and a 4.0mm Titanium rod was contoured for the right and the rods placed into position and secured with set screws. The set screws were then tightened with a final tightener to the appropriate torque. Intraoperative Xray was used to confirm the final position of all implants. This completed the instrumentation of C4, C5, T1, T10, T11, and T12.
I then proceeded with the spinal fusion portion of the procedure. The posterior elements of C4, C5, C6, C7, T1, T10, T11, and T12 were decorticated. Morselized Allograft was then impacted into the lateral gutters and into the facet joints. This completed the posterior spinal fusion procedure of C4-C5, C5-C6, C6-C7, C7-T1, T10-T11, and T11-T12.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned onto the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including posterior spinal instrumentation at C4, C5, T1, T10, T11 and T12, and the posterior spinal fusion at C4-C5, C5-C6, C6-C7, C7-T1, T10-T11 and T11-T12.

Post-operative Diagnosis: Foraminal Stenosis
Indications: Low back pain and left leg pain, resistant to conservative measures.
Procedures Performed: 1. Posterior spinal instrumentation at L4 and L5 2. Transforaminal lumbar interbody fusion and insertion of interbody device at L4-L5 3. Posterior Spinal Fusion at L4-L5 4. Application of Morselized Allograft 5. Spinal Cord Monitoring 6. Application of Cranial Tongs
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: See anesthesia records
Fluids/Transfusions: See Anesthesia Records
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. Cranial tongs were applied to the patient's skull for positioning and an appropriate weight was selected for cranial traction. The patient was then positioned prone on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the L4 level and distally to the L5 level.
I then proceeded with the posterior spinal instrumentation. For pedicle screws, the transverse process, pars, and superior facet were used as landmarks to identify the appropriate starting point. After identifying the start point, the superficial cortex was opened at each entry point using a high speed burr. A pedicle probe was then used to navigate down the pedicle, followed by palpating a medial, lateral, superior and inferior pedicle wall, measuring, and tapping if appropriate. At L4, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L5, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. This partially completed the posterior spinal instrumentation of L4, and L5.
I then proceeded with the transforaminal interbody fusion (TLIF) procedure and placement of interbody implant from the left side at the level of L4-L5. The inferior and superior facets of L4 and L5, respectively, were resected and the exiting and traversing nerve roots were appropriately protected. The annulus was incised, allowing access to the disk space. The disk was excised and endplates were prepped using a combination of currettes, shavers, and pituitary rongeurs. Once the endplates were adequately prepped, trials were used to determine the appropriate size of the implant. At the L4-L5 interspace, an 8mm height Titanium implant was selected. Once I was satisfied with the size of the trial, the interbody implant was placed into the interbody space along with allograft bone. The final position of the implant was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the transforaminal lumbar interbody fusion and insertion of interbody device at the L4-L5 interspace.
To complete the spinal instrumentation, a 5.5mm Titanium rod was contoured for the left and a 5.5mm Titanium rod was contoured for the right and the rods placed into position and secured with set screws. The set screws were then tightened with a final tightener to the appropriate torque. Intraoperative Xray was used to confirm the final position of all implants. This completed the instrumentation of L4, and L5.
I then proceeded with the spinal fusion portion of the procedure. The posterior elements of L4, and L5 were decorticated. To improve the odds of a successful fusion, 4.2mg of BMP was placed into the posterior fusion bed. Morselized Allograft was then impacted into the lateral gutters and into the facet joints. This completed the posterior spinal fusion procedure of L4-L5.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned onto the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including posterior spinal instrumentation at L4 and L5, transforaminal lumbar interbody fusion and insertion of interbody device at L4-L5, and the posterior spinal fusion at L4-L5.
transforaminal lumbar interbody fusion and insertion of interbody device

I then proceeded with the posterior spinal instrumentation. For pedicle screws, the transverse process, pars, and superior facet were used as landmarks to identify the appropriate starting point. I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. At C2, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T1, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T2, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T3, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. For lateral mass screw placement, the entry point was identified using the lateral and medial borders of the lateral mass and superior and inferior borders of the facet. The superficial cortex was opened at each entry point using a high speed burr and the screw path drilled incrementally to the far cortex. At C3, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At C4, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At C5, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At C6, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. This partially completed the posterior spinal instrumentation of C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, T1, T2, and T3.
I then proceeded with the decompression with central laminectomy. Using the cranial and caudal edges of the lamina and pars as landmarks, I performed a laminectomy at C4, C5 and C6. First, using a combination of a high-speed burr and Kerrison rongeurs, I resected the dorsal lamina. I then excised the underlying ligamentum flavum. Following the decompression, the canal was palpated to confirm an adequate decompression had been completed. This completed the decompression with central laminectomy of C4, C5, and C6.
I then proceeded with the decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies. Using a combination of a high-speed burr and Kerrison rongeurs, I performed a partial laminectomy bilaterally at the C2-C3 interspace. First, I resected the dorsal lamina and then excised the ligamentum flavum, exposing the dura. To fully decompress the exiting and traversing nerve roots within the neural foramen and lateral recess, the medial facet was partially excised and a foraminotomy performed on the left and right at the C2-C3 interspace. Following the decompression, the canal and foramen were palpated to confirm an adequate decompression had been completed. This completed the decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies of C2-C3.
To complete the spinal instrumentation, a 3.5mm Titanium rod was contoured for the left and a 3.5mm Titanium rod was contoured for the right and the rods placed into position and secured with set screws. The set screws were then tightened with a final tightener to the appropriate torque. Intraoperative Xray was used to confirm the final position of all implants. This completed the instrumentation of C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, T1, T2, and T3.
I then proceeded with the spinal fusion portion of the procedure. The posterior elements of C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, C7, T1, T2, and T3 were decorticated. Morselized Allograft was then impacted into the lateral gutters and into the facet joints. This completed the posterior spinal fusion procedure of C2-C3, C3-C4, C4-C5, C5-C6, C6-C7, C7-T1, T1-T2, and T2-T3.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned onto the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including posterior spinal instrumentation at C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, T1, T2 and T3, decompression with central laminectomy at C4, C5 and C6, decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies at C2-C3, and the posterior spinal fusion at C2-C3, C3-C4, C4-C5, C5-C6, C6-C7, C7-T1, T1-T2 and T2-T3.
decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies

Patient: Gary Williams
Date of Surgery: 2021-05-25
Primary Surgeon: Buchowski
Surgical Assistants: Hills
Pre-operative Diagnosis: Foraminal Stenosis
Post-operative Diagnosis: Foraminal Stenosis
Indications:
Procedures Performed: 1. Anterior diskectomy and fusion with decompression of the central canal and nerve roots at C6-C7 2. Insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at C6-C7 3. Anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at C6 and C7 4. Spinal Cord Monitoring
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: See anesthesia records
Fluids/Transfusions: See Anesthesia Records
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. The patient was then positioned Supine on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. A standard Left-sided Smith Robinson approach was utilized to get to the anterior cervical spine. The skin, subcutaneous tissue were incised, the platysma was transected, and then blunt dissection was carried out between the sternocleidomastoid and carotid sheath laterally, and trachea and esophogus medially, down to the prevertebral fascia. Once the anterior spine was palpated, fluoroscopy was used to localize and confirm levels. The longus coli was elevated bilaterally from C6 proximally and to C7 distally.
I then proceeded with the diskectomy, decompression, and interbody fusion of the C6-C7 interspace. First, I smoothed the anterior disk space and resected any osteophyte using a combination of a ronguer and burr. Using a combination of knife, currette, pituitary ronguer, and Kerrison rongeurs, the anterior longitudinal ligament was incised, the disc was excised and the superior and inferior endplates were lightly decorticated to prepare the endplates for fusion, taking care not to disrupt the cortical endplate. The endplates were distracted and the posterior longitudinal ligament was adequately excised, fully decompressing the central canal. I worked laterally on the left and right with a Kerrison rongeur, resecting any residual disk or osteophyte and fully decompressing the left and the right exiting nerve roots to complete the bilateral foraminotomies. This completed the anterior diskectomy with decompression of the C6-C7 interspace and partially completed the fusion of C6-C7.
I then proceeded with the insertion of the interbody implant into the C6-C7 interspace. I again confirmed that the endplates were adequately decorticated and appropriately level. Once I was fully satisfied with the preparation of the endplates, I used trials and measured the disk space to determine the appropriate size of the interbody implant. At the C6-C7 interspace, an 8mm height Titanium Biomet Trellos Cage implant was selected. I then inserted the interbody implant into the disk space of C6-C7. The final position was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the anterior interbody implant at C6-C7.
I then proceeded with anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at C6 and C7. I placed an anterior plate spanning C6 and C7. After selecting an appropriately sized plate and length for the screws, I held the plate into position and drilled and tapped the path for the screws. The screws were then inserted sequentially into the vertebral body of C6 and C7 to hold the plate into position. This completed the anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at C6 and C7.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was transferred to the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including anterior diskectomy and fusion with decompression of the central canal and nerve roots at C6-C7, insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at C6-C7, and the anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at C6-C7.
anterior diskectomy and fusion with decompression of the central canal and nerve roots
anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant)
At the C6-C7 interspace, a 8mm height Titanium Biomet Trellos Cage implant was selected.

Patient: Matthew Linomaz
Date of Surgery: 2021-05-27
Primary Surgeon: Buchowski
Surgical Assistants: Hills
Pre-operative Diagnosis: Lumbar Disc Herniation
Post-operative Diagnosis: Lumbar Disc Herniation
Indications: Right leg pain, resistant to conservative measures.
Procedures Performed: 1. Decompression with diskectomy and laminotomy at L5-S1 2. Spinal Cord Monitoring 3. Application of Cranial Tongs
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: See anesthesia records
Fluids/Transfusions: See Anesthesia Records
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. Cranial tongs were applied to the patient's skull for positioning and an appropriate weight was selected for cranial traction. The patient was then positioned prone on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the L5 level and distally to the S1 level.
I then proceeded with the decompression with diskectomy and laminotomy. For a diskectomy, I used the cranial and caudal laminar edges, pars, and facet joints as landmarks. I performed a diskectomy with partial medial facetectomy and foraminotomy on the right at L5-S1 interspace to fully decompress the nerve root. Using a high-speed burr and Kerrison rongeurs, I first performed a foraminotomy and excised the ligamentum flavum. The dural sac was identified and traversing root was protected. The annulus was then incised and the diseased disk materal was removed. Following the decompression, the canal and foramen and lateral recess were palpated to confirm an appropriate decompression had been completed. This completed the decompression with diskectomy and laminotomy of L5-S1.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned onto the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including decompression with diskectomy and laminotomy at L5-S1.

Patient: Sharon Shields
Date of Surgery: 2021-05-27
Primary Surgeon: Buchowski
Surgical Assistants: Hills
Pre-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis
Post-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis
Indications: Low back pain, left leg pain and right leg pain, resistant to conservative measures.
Procedures Performed: 1. Posterior spinal instrumentation at L2, L3, L4, L5 and S1 2. Instrumentation of the Pelvis with S2AI fixation 3. Decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies at L2-L3 4. Posterior column osteotomy at L5-S1 5. Posterior Spinal Fusion at L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5 and L5-S1 6. Application of Morselized Allograft 7. Spinal Cord Monitoring 8. Application of Cranial Tongs
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: See anesthesia records
Fluids/Transfusions: See Anesthesia Records
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. Cranial tongs were applied to the patient's skull for positioning and an appropriate weight was selected for cranial traction. The patient was then positioned prone on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the L2 level and distally to the S1 level.
I then proceeded with the posterior spinal instrumentation. For pedicle screws, the transverse process, pars, and superior facet were used as landmarks to identify the appropriate starting point. After identifying the start point, the superficial cortex was opened at each entry point using a high speed burr. A pedicle probe was then used to navigate down the pedicle, followed by palpating a medial, lateral, superior and inferior pedicle wall, measuring, and tapping if appropriate. At L2, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L3, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L4, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L5, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At S1, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. This partially completed the posterior spinal instrumentation of L2, L3, L4, L5, and S1.
I then proceeded with instrumentation of the pelvis. For S2AI screw insertion, the starting point was identified at the inferior and lateral border of the S1 foramen. A probe was used to bore the path of the screw between the two cortices, across the sacroiliac joint, and aimed toward the anterior inferior iliac spine. Once the path was created, the walls of the path were palpated for breaches and the length of the path measured. Using this technique, a polyaxial S2AI screw was placed on the left and a polyaxial S2AI screw was placed on the right. This completed the instrumentation of the pelvis.
I then proceeded with the decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies. Using a combination of a high-speed burr and Kerrison rongeurs, I performed a partial laminectomy bilaterally at the L2-L3 interspace. First, I resected the dorsal lamina and then excised the ligamentum flavum, exposing the dura. To fully decompress the exiting and traversing nerve roots within the neural foramen and lateral recess, the medial facet was partially excised and a foraminotomy performed on the left and right at the L2-L3 interspace. Following the decompression, the canal and foramen were palpated to confirm an adequate decompression had been completed. This completed the decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies of L2-L3.
I then proceeded with the posterior column osteotomy. For the posterior column osteotomies, a small rent was made in the interlaminar space to develop the plane between the ligamentum and the dura. A Kerrison rongeur was then used to excise the ligamentum. this was carried out laterally in both directions until the facets were encountered. The superior and inferior facet were both adequately resected to fully release the posterior column. I performed posterior column (Smith-Peterson) osteotomies at L5-S1 This completed the posterior column osteotomy of L5-S1.
To complete the spinal instrumentation, a 5.5mm Titanium rod was contoured for the left and a 5.5mm Titanium rod was contoured for the right and the rods placed into position and secured with set screws. The set screws were then tightened with a final tightener to the appropriate torque. Intraoperative Xray was used to confirm the final position of all implants. This completed the instrumentation of L2, L3, L4, L5, S1, and S2AI.
I then proceeded with the spinal fusion portion of the procedure. The posterior elements of L2, L3, L4, L5, and S1 were decorticated. To improve the odds of a successful fusion, 24mg of BMP was placed into the posterior fusion bed. Morselized Allograft was then impacted into the lateral gutters and into the facet joints. This completed the posterior spinal fusion procedure of L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5, and L5-S1.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned onto the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including posterior spinal instrumentation at L2, L3, L4, L5 and S1, pelvic instrumentation at S2AI, decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies at L2-L3, posterior column osteotomy at L5-S1, and the posterior spinal fusion at L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5 and L5-S1.
decompression with bilateral partial laminectomies, foraminotomies, and medial facetectomies

Patient: Patricia Anderson
Date of Surgery: 2021-05-27
Primary Surgeon: Buchowski
Surgical Assistants: Hills
Pre-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis and Myelopathy
Post-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis and Myelopathy
Indications: Myelopathy: nurick 3 (gait abnormalities), resistant to conservative measures.
Procedures Performed: 1. Laminoplasty at C4, C5 and C6 2. Decompression with central laminectomy at C3 3. Spinal Cord Monitoring 4. Application of Cranial Tongs
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: See anesthesia records
Fluids/Transfusions: See Anesthesia Records
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. Cranial tongs were applied to the patient's skull for positioning and an appropriate weight was selected for cranial traction. The patient was then positioned prone on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the C3 level and distally to the C6 level.
I then proceeded with the laminoplasty. For laminoplasty, an opening and hinge trough was created with a high-speed burr angled perpendicular to the lamina at the lateral mass-lamina junction. This was performed at C4, C5 and C6. After all troughs were completed, greenstick fractures were created to open the lamina at the laminoplasty levels, the ligamentum flavum at the proximal and distal levels was excised, and laminoplasty plates were sequentially secured into place. The spinous processes were trimmed and the canal was palpated to confirm an adequate decompression had been completed. This completed the laminoplasty of C4, C5, and C6.
I then proceeded with the decompression with central laminectomy. Using the cranial and caudal edges of the lamina and pars as landmarks, I performed a laminectomy at C3. First, using a combination of a high-speed burr and Kerrison rongeurs, I resected the dorsal lamina. I then excised the underlying ligamentum flavum. Following the decompression, the canal was palpated to confirm an adequate decompression had been completed. This completed the decompression with central laminectomy of C3.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned onto the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including laminoplasty at C4, C5 and C6, and the decompression with central laminectomy at C3.
low back pain; left leg pain; right leg pain

The patient was then positioned prone on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the T2 level and distally to the T6 level.
I then proceeded with the posterior spinal instrumentation. For pedicle screws, the transverse process, pars, and superior facet were used as landmarks to identify the appropriate starting point. After identifying the start point, the superficial cortex was opened at each entry point using a high speed burr. A pedicle probe was then used to navigate down the pedicle, followed by palpating a medial, lateral, superior and inferior pedicle wall, measuring, and tapping if appropriate. At T2, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T3, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T4, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T5, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T6, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. This partially completed the posterior spinal instrumentation of T2, T3, T4, T5, and T6.
To complete the spinal instrumentation, a 5.5mm Titanium rod was contoured for the left and a 5.5mm Titanium rod was contoured for the right and the rods placed into position and secured with set screws. The set screws were then tightened with a final tightener to the appropriate torque. Intraoperative Xray was used to confirm the final position of all implants. This completed the instrumentation of T2, T3, T4, T5, and T6.
I then proceeded with the spinal fusion portion of the procedure. The posterior elements of T2, T3, T4, T5, and T6 were decorticated. To improve the odds of a successful fusion, 12mg of BMP was placed into the posterior fusion bed. Morselized Allograft was then impacted into the lateral gutters and into the facet joints. This completed the posterior spinal fusion procedure of T2-T3, T3-T4, T4-T5, and T5-T6.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned onto the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including posterior spinal instrumentation at T2, T3, T4, T5 and T6, posterior spinal fusion at T2-T3, T3-T4, T4-T5 and T5-T6, and the open treatment of vertebral fracture.

Patient: George Dasho
Date of Surgery: 2021-06-07
Primary Surgeon: Gupta
Surgical Assistants: Hills
Pre-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis
Post-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis
Indications: Neck pain, left arm pain and right arm pain, resistant to conservative measures.
Procedures Performed: 1. Anterior diskectomy and fusion with decompression of the central canal and nerve roots at C3-C4 2. Anterior diskectomy and fusion with decompression of the central canal and nerve roots at C4-C5 3. Insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at C3-C4 4. Insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at C4-C5 5. Anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at C3, C4 and C5 6. Spinal Cord Monitoring
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: See anesthesia records
Fluids/Transfusions: See Anesthesia Records
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. The patient was then positioned Supine on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. A standard Left-sided Smith Robinson approach was utilized to get to the anterior cervical spine. The skin, subcutaneous tissue were incised, the platysma was transected, and then blunt dissection was carried out between the sternocleidomastoid and carotid sheath laterally, and trachea and esophogus medially, down to the prevertebral fascia. Once the anterior spine was palpated, fluoroscopy was used to localize and confirm levels. The longus coli was elevated bilaterally from C3 proximally and to C5 distally.
I then proceeded with the diskectomy, decompression, and interbody fusion of the C3-C4 interspace. First, I smoothed the anterior disk space and resected any osteophyte using a combination of a ronguer and burr. Using a combination of knife, currette, pituitary ronguer, and Kerrison rongeurs, the anterior longitudinal ligament was incised, the disc was excised and the superior and inferior endplates were lightly decorticated to prepare the endplates for fusion, taking care not to disrupt the cortical endplate. The endplates were distracted and the posterior longitudinal ligament was adequately excised, fully decompressing the central canal. I worked laterally on the left and right with a Kerrison rongeur, resecting any residual disk or osteophyte and fully decompressing the left and the right exiting nerve roots to complete the bilateral foraminotomies. This completed the anterior diskectomy with decompression of the C3-C4 interspace and partially completed the fusion of C3-C4.
I then proceeded with the diskectomy, decompression, and interbody fusion of the C4-C5 interspace. First, I smoothed the anterior disk space and resected any osteophyte using a combination of a ronguer and burr. Using a combination of knife, currette, pituitary ronguer, and Kerrison rongeurs, the anterior longitudinal ligament was incised, the disc was excised and the superior and inferior endplates were lightly decorticated to prepare the endplates for fusion, taking care not to disrupt the cortical endplate. The endplates were distracted and the posterior longitudinal ligament was adequately excised, fully decompressing the central canal. I worked laterally on the left and right with a Kerrison rongeur, resecting any residual disk or osteophyte and fully decompressing the left and the right exiting nerve roots to complete the bilateral foraminotomies. This completed the anterior diskectomy with decompression of the C4-C5 interspace and partially completed the fusion of C4-C5.
I then proceeded with the insertion of the interbody implant into the C3-C4 interspace. I again confirmed that the endplates were adequately decorticated and appropriately level. Once I was fully satisfied with the preparation of the endplates, I used trials and measured the disk space to determine the appropriate size of the interbody implant. At the C3-C4 interspace, an 8mm height implant was selected. I then inserted the interbody implant into the disk space of C3-C4. The final position was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the anterior interbody implant at C3-C4.
I then proceeded with the insertion of the interbody implant into the C4-C5 interspace. I again confirmed that the endplates were adequately decorticated and appropriately level. Once I was fully satisfied with the preparation of the endplates, I used trials and measured the disk space to determine the appropriate size of the interbody implant. At the C4-C5 interspace, an 8mm height implant was selected. I then inserted the interbody implant into the disk space of C4-C5. The final position was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the anterior interbody implant at C4-C5.
I then proceeded with anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at C3, C4 and C5. I placed an anterior plate spanning C3, C4 and C5. After selecting an appropriately sized plate and length for the screws, I held the plate into position and drilled and tapped the path for the screws. The screws were then inserted sequentially into the vertebral body of C3, C4 and C5 to hold the plate into position. This completed the anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at C3, C4 and C5.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was transferred to the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including anterior diskectomy and fusion with decompression of the central canal and nerve roots at C3-C4, anterior diskectomy and fusion with decompression of the central canal and nerve roots at C4-C5, insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at C3-C4, insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at C4-C5, and the anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at C3-C4 and C4-C5.
anterior diskectomy and fusion with decompression of the central canal and nerve roots
anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant)

Patient: Angela Guithrues
Date of Surgery: 2021-06-09
Primary Surgeon: Gupta
Surgical Assistants: Hills
Pre-operative Diagnosis: Flatback Syndrome
Post-operative Diagnosis: Flatback Syndrome
Indications: Low back pain, left leg pain and right leg pain, resistant to conservative measures.
Procedures Performed: 1. Posterior spinal instrumentation at T5, T6, T7, T8, T9, T10, T11, T12, L2, L3, L5 and S1 2. Instrumentation of the Pelvis with Iliac fixation 3. Spinous process posterior tethering/wiring at T4 and T5 4. Extended three column osteotomy (vertebral body partial corpectomy) at L4 5. Posterior Spinal Fusion at T5-T6, T6-T7, T7-T8, T8-T9, T9-T10, T10-T11, T11-T12, T12-L1, L1-L2, L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5 and L5-S1 6. Application of Morselized Allograft 7. Spinal Cord Monitoring 8. Application of Cranial Tongs
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: See anesthesia records
Fluids/Transfusions: See Anesthesia Records
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. Cranial tongs were applied to the patient's skull for positioning and an appropriate weight was selected for cranial traction. The patient was then positioned prone on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the T4 level and distally to the S1 level.
I then proceeded with the posterior spinal instrumentation. For pedicle screws, the transverse process, pars, and superior facet were used as landmarks to identify the appropriate starting point. After identifying the start point, the superficial cortex was opened at each entry point using a high speed burr. A pedicle probe was then used to navigate down the pedicle, followed by palpating a medial, lateral, superior and inferior pedicle wall, measuring, and tapping if appropriate. At T6, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T7, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T8, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T9, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T10, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T11, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At T12, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L2, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L3, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L5, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At S1, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. For transverse process hooks, the cranial edge of the transverse process was identified. A transverse process finder was used to develop the plane and a transverse process hook was placed securely into position along the superior edge of the transverse process. This partially completed the posterior spinal instrumentation of T5, T6, T7, T8, T9, T10, T11, T12, L2, L3, L5, and S1.
I then proceeded with instrumentation of the pelvis. For iliac screw insertion, the posterior iliac crest was identified and the entry point was countersunk using a rongeur. A probe was used to bore the path of the screw between the two cortices, aimed toward the anterior inferior iliac spine. Once the path was created, the walls of the path were palpated for breaches and the length of the path measured. Using this technique, a polyaxial iliac screw was placed on the left and a polyaxial iliac screw was placed on the right. This completed the instrumentation of the pelvis.
I then proceeded with the spinous process posterior tethering/wiring. For posterior vertebral tethering, a hole was drilled in the transverse process over the lamina. A band was then thread through the hole and tied in a figure-8 fashion, tethering T4 and T5. This completed the spinous process posterior tethering/wiring of T4, and T5.
I then proceeded with an extended three column osteotomy (partial corpectomy) at the level of L4. The posterior elements of L4 were completely removed. A complete central laminectomy was performed and confirmed at the L3 level in order to prevent compression after osteotomy closure. A temporary rod was placed and starting on the contralateral side, a complete superior facetectomy was performed and any dorsal bone and scar was removed, and the L3 nerve root was visualized and tracked laterally. Then a cut was made through the pars just inferior to the pedicle, and the superior facet of the inferior vertebra was resected, allowing the L4 nerve root to be visualized and tracked laterally. Next, the transverse process was resected. Once the L4 pedicle was completely skeletonized, and the cranial and caudal nerve roots identified and a full decompression was confirmed from the L3 pedicle to the L5 pedicle, a subperiosteal plane was developed around the anterior portion of the L4 body and retractors were held in place to protect the retroperitoneal structures. Next, the pedicle was resected down to the dorsal vertebral body, leaving a lip medially to protect the neural structures. The dura, cranial and caudal nerve roots were protected and a high speed burr was used to develop a defect in the vertebral body. The lateral portion of the pedicle wall was taken down, allowing easier access to the vertebral body and the vertebral body was hollowed out, extending up into the cranial disk space, taking care not to perforate the anterior cortex. The remaining pedicle walls were then resected with a box osteotome. We then placed a temporary rod and repeated the same process on the contralateral pedicle. Once roughly 50% of the vertebral body had been resected, the dorsal wall of the vertebral body was impacted. The nerve roots were checked again and the underside of the thecal sac was palpated to confirm no bony impingement. Once we were satisfied that the thecal sac was fully decompressed circumferentially and that the L3 and L4 nerve roots were completely free, the osteotomy was closed, and the other rod was placed into position and set screws final tightened to lock the osteotomy in position. Intraoperative xray was performed to confirm appropriate alignment. This completed the extended three column osteotomy (vertebral body partial corpectomy) at the L4 level.
To complete the spinal instrumentation, a 5.5mm Cobalt Chrome rod was contoured for the left and a 5.5mm Cobalt Chrome rod was contoured for the right and the rods placed into position and secured with set screws. On the left side, a satellite rod construct was utilized, with the satellite rod spanning L3 to L5. On the right side, a satellite rod construct was utilized, with the satellite rod spanning L3 to L5. The set screws were then tightened with a final tightener to the appropriate torque. Intraoperative Xray was used to confirm the final position of all implants. This completed the instrumentation of T5, T6, T7, T8, T9, T10, T11, T12, L2, L3, L5, S1, and Iliac.
I then proceeded with the spinal fusion portion of the procedure. The posterior elements of T5, T6, T7, T8, T9, T10, T11, T12, L1, L2, L3, L4, L5, and S1 were decorticated. To improve the odds of a successful fusion, 36mg of BMP was placed into the posterior fusion bed. Morselized Allograft was then impacted into the lateral gutters and into the facet joints. This completed the posterior spinal fusion procedure of T5-T6, T6-T7, T7-T8, T8-T9, T9-T10, T10-T11, T11-T12, T12-L1, L1-L2, L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5, and L5-S1.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned onto the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including posterior spinal instrumentation at T5, T6, T7, T8, T9, T10, T11, T12, L2, L3, L5 and S1, pelvic instrumentation at Iliac, spinous process posterior tethering/wiring at T4 and T5, extended three column osteotomy (vertebral body partial corpectomy) at L4, and the posterior spinal fusion at T5-T6, T6-T7, T7-T8, T8-T9, T9-T10, T10-T11, T11-T12, T12-L1, L1-L2, L2-L3, L3-L4, L4-L5 and L5-S1.
extended three column osteotomy (vertebral body partial corpectomy)

Patient: Eleanore Trujillo Tiroch

Indications: Low back pain and left leg pain, resistant to conservative measures.
Procedures Performed: Anterior: 1. Anterior diskectomy and fusion at L4-L5 2. Anterior diskectomy and fusion at L5-S1 3. Insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at L4-L5 4. Insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at L5-S1 5. Anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at L5 and S1 6. Application of Morselized Allograft 7. Spinal Cord Monitoring
Posterior: 1. Posterior spinal instrumentation at L4, L5 and S1 2. Decompression with central laminectomy at L4 and L5 3. Posterior Spinal Fusion at L4-L5 and L5-S1 4. Application of Morselized Allograft 5. Spinal Cord Monitoring 6. Application of Cranial Tongs
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: See anesthesia records
Fluids/Transfusions: See Anesthesia Records
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: Anterior: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. The patient was then positioned Supine on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. The anterior approach to the spine was carried out with assistance from our vascular surgeon. A Left-sided incision was made and the approach was carried out down toward the spine. Once the approach was complete, levels were confirmed using fluoroscopy.
I then proceeded with the diskectomy and interbody fusion of the L4-L5 interspace. First, I smoothed the anterior disk space and resected any osteophyte using a combination of a ronguer and burr. Using a combination of knife, currette, pituitary ronguer, and Kerrison rongeurs, the anterior longitudinal ligament was incised, the disc was excised and the superior and inferior endplates were lightly decorticated to prepare the endplates for fusion, taking care not to disrupt the cortical endplate. This completed the anterior diskectomy of L4-L5 interspace and partially completed the fusion of L4-L5.
I then proceeded with the diskectomy and interbody fusion of the L5-S1 interspace. First, I smoothed the anterior disk space and resected any osteophyte using a combination of a ronguer and burr. Using a combination of knife, currette, pituitary ronguer, and Kerrison rongeurs, the anterior longitudinal ligament was incised, the disc was excised and the superior and inferior endplates were lightly decorticated to prepare the endplates for fusion, taking care not to disrupt the cortical endplate. This completed the anterior diskectomy of L5-S1 interspace and partially completed the fusion of L5-S1.
I then proceeded with the insertion of the interbody implant into the L4-L5 interspace. I again confirmed that the endplates were adequately decorticated and appropriately level. Once I was fully satisfied with the preparation of the endplates, I used trials and measured the disk space to determine the appropriate size of the interbody implant. At the L4-L5 interspace, an 8mm height Allograft implant was selected. I then inserted the interbody implant into the disk space of L4-L5. The final position was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the anterior interbody implant at L4-L5.
I then proceeded with the insertion of the interbody implant into the L5-S1 interspace. I again confirmed that the endplates were adequately decorticated and appropriately level. Once I was fully satisfied with the preparation of the endplates, I used trials and measured the disk space to determine the appropriate size of the interbody implant. At the L5-S1 interspace, an 8mm height Allograft implant was selected. I then inserted the interbody implant into the disk space of L5-S1. The final position was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the anterior interbody implant at L5-S1.
I then proceeded with anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at L5 and S1. At the S1 level, I placed a screw to work as a buttress. The midline of the anterior vertebral endplate was identified and a drill was used to create a trajectory for the screw. I then inserted the screw the into the S1 vertebral body. At the L5 level, I placed a screw to work as a buttress. The midline of the anterior vertebral endplate was identified and a drill was used to create a trajectory for the screw. I then inserted the screw the into the L5 vertebral body. This completed the anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at L5 and S1.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and we prepared for the next portion of the procedure. I was personally present for the entirety of this portion of the case, including anterior diskectomy and fusion at L4-L5, anterior diskectomy and fusion at L5-S1, insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at L4-L5, insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at L5-S1, and the anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at L5 and S1.
We then turned to the posterior portion of the case.
The patient was then positioned prone on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. Cranial tongs applied to the patient's skull with an appropriate weight for cranial traction was used to position the head. The posterior spine was then prepped and draped in the standard fashion. A standard posterior approach to the spine was performed, exposing proximally to the L4 level and distally to the S1 level.
I then proceeded with the posterior spinal instrumentation. For pedicle screws, the transverse process, pars, and superior facet were used as landmarks to identify the appropriate starting point. After identifying the start point, the superficial cortex was opened at each entry point using a high speed burr. A pedicle probe was then used to navigate down the pedicle, followed by palpating a medial, lateral, superior and inferior pedicle wall, measuring, and tapping if appropriate. At L4, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At L5, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. At S1, a polyaxial screw was inserted on the left and a polyaxial screw was inserted on the right. This partially completed the posterior spinal instrumentation of L4, L5, and S1.
I then proceeded with the decompression with central laminectomy. Using the cranial and caudal edges of the lamina and pars as landmarks, I performed a laminectomy at L4 and L5. First, using a combination of a high-speed burr and Kerrison rongeurs, I resected the dorsal lamina. I then excised the underlying ligamentum flavum. Following the decompression, the canal was palpated to confirm an adequate decompression had been completed. This completed the decompression with central laminectomy of L4, and L5.
To complete the spinal instrumentation, a 5.5mm Titanium rod was contoured for the left and a 5.5mm Titanium rod was contoured for the right and the rods placed into position and secured with set screws. The set screws were then tightened with a final tightener to the appropriate torque. Intraoperative Xray was used to confirm the final position of all implants. This completed the instrumentation of L4, L5, and S1.
I then proceeded with the spinal fusion portion of the procedure. The posterior elements of L4, L5, and S1 were decorticated. To improve the odds of a successful fusion, 12mg of BMP was placed into the posterior fusion bed. A total of 60(cc) of Morselized allograft was then impacted into the lateral gutters and into the facet joints. This completed the posterior spinal fusion procedure of L4-L5, and L5-S1.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. Vancomycin Powder was then placed into the surgical bed. One drain was placed deep to the fascial layer. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The fascial layer was closed with a watertight closure. One drain was placed superficial to the fascial layer. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, Steristrips, and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was turned uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of this portion of the case, including posterior spinal instrumentation at L4, L5 and S1, decompression with central laminectomy at L4 and L5, and the posterior spinal fusion at L4-L5 and L5-S1.
anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant)
At the L4-L5 interspace, a 8mm height Allograft implant was selected.
At the L5-S1 interspace, a 8mm height Allograft implant was selected.

Patient: Patricia Csengody
Date of Surgery: 2021-07-28
Primary Surgeon: Kelly
Surgical Assistants: Hills
Pre-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis and Myelopathy
Post-operative Diagnosis: Spinal Stenosis and Myelopathy
Indications: Neck pain, resistant to conservative measures.
Procedures Performed: 1. Anterior diskectomy and fusion with decompression of the central canal and nerve roots at C4-C5 2. Anterior diskectomy and fusion with decompression of the central canal and nerve roots at C5-C6 3. Anterior diskectomy and fusion with decompression of the central canal and nerve roots at C6-C7 4. Insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at C4-C5 5. Insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at C5-C6 6. Insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at C6-C7 7. Anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at C4, C5, C6 and C7 8. Spinal Cord Monitoring
Surgical Findings: none
Specimens Removed: none
Estimated Blood Loss: 50
Fluids/Transfusions: See Anesthesia Records
Intraoperative Complications: none
Surgery Description: The patient was brought to the operating room and after obtaining appropriate IV access, the patient underwent general anesthesia. Preoperative Antibiotics were administered including Cefazolin (Ancef) and Vancomycin . Spinal Cord Monitoring needles were inserted by the neurophysiology technologist. The patient was then positioned Supine on the OR table and all bony prominences were appropriately padded. After prepping and draping in the standard fashion, a surgical timeout was performed. A standard Left-sided Smith Robinson approach was utilized to get to the anterior cervical spine. The skin, subcutaneous tissue were incised, the platysma was transected, and then blunt dissection was carried out between the sternocleidomastoid and carotid sheath laterally, and trachea and esophogus medially, down to the prevertebral fascia. Once the anterior spine was palpated, fluoroscopy was used to localize and confirm levels. The longus coli was elevated bilaterally from C4 proximally and to C7 distally.
I then proceeded with the diskectomy, decompression, and interbody fusion of the C4-C5 interspace. First, I smoothed the anterior disk space and resected any osteophyte using a combination of a ronguer and burr. Using a combination of knife, currette, pituitary ronguer, and Kerrison rongeurs, the anterior longitudinal ligament was incised, the disc was excised and the superior and inferior endplates were lightly decorticated to prepare the endplates for fusion, taking care not to disrupt the cortical endplate. The endplates were distracted and posterior osteophyte excised, fully decompressing the central canal. I worked laterally on the left and right with a Kerrison rongeur, resecting any residual disk or osteophyte and fully decompressing the left and the right exiting nerve roots to complete the bilateral foraminotomies. This completed the anterior diskectomy with decompression of the C4-C5 interspace and partially completed the fusion of C4-C5.
I then proceeded with the insertion of the interbody implant into the C4-C5 interspace. I again confirmed that the endplates were adequately decorticated and appropriately level. Once I was fully satisfied with the preparation of the endplates, I used trials and measured the disk space to determine the appropriate size of the interbody implant. At the C4-C5 interspace, an 8mm height Allograft implant was selected. I then inserted the interbody implant into the disk space of C4-C5. The final position was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the anterior interbody implant at C4-C5.
I then proceeded with the diskectomy, decompression, and interbody fusion of the C5-C6 interspace. First, I smoothed the anterior disk space and resected any osteophyte using a combination of a ronguer and burr. Using a combination of knife, currette, pituitary ronguer, and Kerrison rongeurs, the anterior longitudinal ligament was incised, the disc was excised and the superior and inferior endplates were lightly decorticated to prepare the endplates for fusion, taking care not to disrupt the cortical endplate. The endplates were distracted and the posterior osteophyte excised, fully decompressing the central canal. I worked laterally on the left and right with a Kerrison rongeur, resecting any residual disk or osteophyte and fully decompressing the left and the right exiting nerve roots to complete the bilateral foraminotomies. This completed the anterior diskectomy with decompression of the C5-C6 interspace and partially completed the fusion of C5-C6.
I then proceeded with the insertion of the interbody implant into the C5-C6 interspace. I again confirmed that the endplates were adequately decorticated and appropriately level. Once I was fully satisfied with the preparation of the endplates, I used trials and measured the disk space to determine the appropriate size of the interbody implant. At the C5-C6 interspace, a 7mm height Allograft implant was selected. I then inserted the interbody implant into the disk space of C5-C6. The final position was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the anterior interbody implant at C5-C6.
I then proceeded with the diskectomy, decompression, and interbody fusion of the C6-C7 interspace. First, I smoothed the anterior disk space and resected any osteophyte using a combination of a ronguer and burr. Using a combination of knife, currette, pituitary ronguer, and Kerrison rongeurs, the anterior longitudinal ligament was incised, the disc was excised and the superior and inferior endplates were lightly decorticated to prepare the endplates for fusion, taking care not to disrupt the cortical endplate. The endplates were distracted and the posterior osteophyte excised, fully decompressing the central canal. I worked laterally on the left and right with a Kerrison rongeur, resecting any residual disk or osteophyte and fully decompressing the left and the right exiting nerve roots to complete the bilateral foraminotomies. This completed the anterior diskectomy with decompression of the C6-C7 interspace and partially completed the fusion of C6-C7.
I then proceeded with the insertion of the interbody implant into the C6-C7 interspace. I again confirmed that the endplates were adequately decorticated and appropriately level. Once I was fully satisfied with the preparation of the endplates, I used trials and measured the disk space to determine the appropriate size of the interbody implant. At the C6-C7 interspace, an 8mm height Allograft implant was selected. I then inserted the interbody implant into the disk space of C6-C7. The final position was confirmed using intraoperative xray. This completed the anterior interbody implant at C6-C7.
I then proceeded with anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at C4, C5, C6 and C7. I placed an anterior plate spanning C4, C5, C6 and C7. After selecting an appropriately sized plate and length for the screws, I held the plate into position and drilled and tapped the path for the screws. The screws were then inserted sequentially into the vertebral body of C4, C5, C6 and C7 to hold the plate into position. This completed the anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at C4, C5, C6 and C7.
I then proceeded with closure of the wound. The wound was then closed in a layered fashion. The subdermal layer was closed and subcutaneous suture was used to close the skin layer. Lastly, dermabond and a water tight dressing was applied to the surgical site.
At the conclusion of the case, all counts were correct. The drapes were removed and the patient was transferred to the hospital bed, and awoke uneventfully. I was personally present for the entirety of the case, including anterior diskectomy and fusion with decompression of the central canal and nerve roots at C4-C5, anterior diskectomy and fusion with decompression of the central canal and nerve roots at C5-C6, anterior diskectomy and fusion with decompression of the central canal and nerve roots at C6-C7, insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at C4-C5, insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at C5-C6, insertion of interbody biomechanical implant at C6-C7, and the anterior spinal instrumentation (distinct from an interbody implant) at C4-C5, C5-C6 and C6-C7.

At the C5-C6 interspace, a 7mm height Allograft implant was selected.
